title: Viola Davis stuns crowd with 'Fences' acceptance speech at Oscars
text:
Viola Davis had the crowd in tears during her acceptance speech at the Oscars Sunday night.
After winning best supporting actress for her role in “Fences,” Davis broke down in tears talking about her upbringing.
“There's one place where all the people with the greatest potential are gathered. One place. And that's the graveyard,” she said on stage.
“People ask me all the time, ‘what sort of stories do you want to tell, Viola?’ And I say exhume those bodies. Exhume those stories. The stories of the people who dreamed big and never saw those stories to fruition. People who fell in love and lost.”
Mahershala Ali becomes the first Muslim actor to win an Oscar 
Viola Davis’ acceptance speech at the Oscars was a heartwarming message of appreciation for her role in telling “the stories of the people who dreamed big and never saw those stories to fruition.” (Kevin Winter/Getty Images) With her win, the 51-year-old actress became the first black actor to win an Oscar , an Emmy and a Tony award.
“I became an artist and thank god I did because we are the only profession that celebrates what it means to live a life,” Davis said on stage.
The speech, which brought the crowd to tears, also drew rave reviews online.

“I (guess) there can't be a GOD without a GODDESS,” Wesley Snipes wrote. “Thank you for the Gift of YOU.”
“When journalists ask me "what's it like to work with Viola Davis" for the 100th time I'm gonna bottle these tears and show em. "LOOK! See?!" tweeted “How to Get Away with Murder” co-star Jack Falahee.
Viola Davis won best supporting actress for her role in “Fences” at the Oscars Sunday. (Photo credit: David Lee/David Lee) “Viola Davis, you are a national treasure,” wrote Ellen DeGeneres.
Even host Jimmy Kimmel ad-libbed his own joke about the touching message.
